It might also be noted that FCC Chairman Minow announced in his
keynote address before the NAEB Convention that the FCC has set up a
section devoted exclusively to education and research. I do not know
exactly what he meant by research in this instance, but it might be well
to consult with someone at FCC to determine exactly what their hope for
development and research might be.
In other words, I think that some effort and coordination or consultation
of all these research oriented and interested groups - NAEB, NAB, APBE
and FCC - might prove profitable. At this moment I have no other sugges-
tions to make regarding Harley’s idea. I hope these have been somewhat
helpful and, I would, of course, be interested in helping anyway possible
to implement any research center which would bring more and better re¬
search studies in broadcasting.11
The other two committee members had serious reservations. Here are
their comments:
Schramm: "I don’t know that I fully understand this plan which came
by you out of Bill Harley, but if I do understand it I’m not very enthu¬
siastic. Let me ask a few questions which will probably convey my feeling
tone.
If this is to be purely a local operation •- i.e., NAEB puts an
enquiring station into touch with a local survey research outfit -- what
does the national research director do? (I am not implying that it wouldn’t
be a good idea for NAEB to sponsor research from a national outlook, but
don’t see exactly what a permanent, full-time research director in Washing¬
ton would do in this case; nor, indeed, how they could make it exciting
enough to get a really good man.)
Along the same line, what is this $30,000 for the national office to
do? (Once again, I am all in favor of the national office getting more
money, but how does this contribute to the project?)
Again, is this the best way to find out what audiences want and need?
I am sure you will agree that people are pretty inarticulate about what
new and different kinds of programs they want -- and even more about what
they need. Would a better way be for the station to talk with representa¬
tive leaders, perhaps to maintain a continuing program advisory council of
such leaders? Frankly, I suspect that such surveys would be used as a
delaying action by a station -- we have brought in this organization, spon¬
sored by the NAEB, to survey our audience, and we are making maximum use
of the results; in fact, if you will look at these responses, you will
see that 871 of our audience had no concrete suggestions to make, and
therefore were evidently completely satisfied, etc. Remember that this
is research work to be done for the station; it isn’t an outside evalua¬
tion of programs. The station would have complete right to use the results,
and even to specify what is asked. I'm not really very hopeful that this
would make a fundamental difference.
